customer_name: Dennis L and Sarah A Hershberger
site_name: Dennis L and Sarah A Hershberger

citations.narrative:
A method of identification for puppies less than 16 weeks old, who are not yet microchipped, is not currently being used.
The cage cards at the facilities do not individually identify puppies before they are microchipped. The puppies also do not
have collars, nor are they identified on a APHIS 7005 form. Cage cards can be an accepted form of identification as long
as:
- The puppies be maintained as distinct litters at the facility where born, and
• The cage card must be attached to the outside of the enclosure, and
• Cage cards must be completed as soon as possible, preferably one or two days after each animal's birth, and
• Must include an individual ID number for each puppy, and
• The cage card may only be used as identification until the puppies are sold or moved from the facility where they were
born or reach 16 weeks of age, whichever comes first, and
• If the cage card is used for both ID and record keeping purposes, it must be retained for one year after use.
Proper identification of puppies is important for disease identification, treatment, and trace back, or in cases of theft or
loss. Class "A" dealers shall identify all live dogs on the premises. Correct by ensuring proper identification is used,
documented, and maintained for all dogs at the facility. Correct by May 12, 2024.

The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care for vaccinations. Of the 36 adult dogs, none are up to date on the
rabies vaccine, a required vaccination. Thirty of the dogs have no history of receiving a rabies vaccine. Five dogs have
had a rabies vaccine in the past but are overdue. One dog has no history of receiving a distemper, parvovirus, or rabies
vaccine. The current Program of Vet Care prescribes for the rabies vaccine to be performed yearly and then every 3
years. The distemper and parvovirus vaccines are prescribed to be given yearly. The licensee states she was not aware
the rabies vaccine was required.
The following 30 dogs have no history of receiving a rabies vaccine:
- Adult female Bichon “Patsy” #2330
- Adult female Bichon “Betsy” #4038
- Adult female Bichon “Stacy” #3401
- Adult female Bichon “Prixy” #2078
- Adult female Bichon “Tammy” #6071

- Adult female Bichon “Chelsie” #6974
- Adult female Bichon “Bella” #6626
- Adult female Cavalier “Sheila” #7818
- Adult female Cavalier “Frosty” #3390
- Adult female Cavalier “Sally” #2362
- Adult male Shih Tzu “Friskee” #9887
- Adult male Poodle “Turbo” #3396
- Adult female Havanese “Shiann” #8230
- Adult female Havanese “Abby” #5953
- Adult female Havanese “Cristal” #8226
- Adult female Havanese “Twinkle” #3185

- Adult female Havanese “Heather” #0050
- Adult female Havanese “Goldie” #2322

- Adult female Havanese “Shari” #4295
- Adult female Havanese “Tasha” #3393
- Adult female Havanese “Tillie” #9756
- Adult female Havanese “Zoey” #9750
- Adult female Havanese “Coffee” #4854
- Adult female Havanese “Silver” #4873
- Adult male Havanese “Bingo” #1459
The following 5 dogs have a history of receiving the rabies vaccine but are now overdue:
- Adult male Bichon “Buster” #5626 had a rabies vaccine on 1-1-22 and was due on 1-1-23 for another rabies vaccine.
The rabies vaccine is 1 year and 4 months overdue.
- Adult male Cavalier “Star” #4809 and adult female Havanese “Lucy” #4818 had a rabies vaccine on 12-15-22 and were
due on 12-15-23 for another rabies vaccine. The rabies vaccine is 5 months overdue.
- Adult female Havanese “Moxie” #9990 had a rabies vaccine on 9-19-17 and was due on 9-19-18 for another rabies
vaccine. The rabies vaccine is 5 years and 8 months overdue.
- Adult female Havanese “Maggie” #8230 had a rabies vaccine on 8-31-22 and was due on 8-31-23 for another rabies
vaccine. The rabies vaccine is 9 months overdue.
The following 1 dog has no history of vaccinations for distemper, parvovirus, or rabies:
- Adult male Cavalier “Asher” #0537
Distemper, parvovirus, and rabies are life-threatening diseases, and, if contracted, may cause pain, distress, and
suffering. Correct by vaccinating for distemper, parvovirus, and rabies in accordance with a schedule approved by the
Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations. Correct by May 12, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
A method of identification for puppies less than 16 weeks old, who are not yet microchipped, is not currently being used. 
The cage cards at the facilities do not individually identify puppies before they are microchipped. The puppies also do not 
have collars, nor are they identified on a APHIS 7005 form. Cage cards can be an accepted form of identification as long 
as:  
- The puppies be maintained as distinct litters at the facility where born, and 
• The cage card must be attached to the outside of the enclosure, and 
• Cage cards must be completed as soon as possible, preferably one or two days after each animal's birth, and 
• Must include an individual ID number for each puppy, and 
• The cage card may only be used as identification until the puppies are sold or moved from the facility where they were 
born or reach 16 weeks of age, whichever comes first, and 
• If the cage card is used for both ID and record keeping purposes, it must be retained for one year after use. 
 
Proper identification of puppies is important for disease identification, treatment, and trace back, or in cases of theft or 
loss. Class "A" dealers shall identify all live dogs on the premises. Correct by ensuring proper identification is used, 
documented, and maintained for all dogs at the facility. Correct by May 12, 2024. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care for vaccinations. Of the 36 adult dogs, none are up to date on the 
rabies vaccine, a required vaccination. Thirty of the dogs have no history of receiving a rabies vaccine. Five dogs have 
had a rabies vaccine in the past but are overdue. One dog has no history of receiving a distemper, parvovirus, or rabies 
vaccine. The current Program of Vet Care prescribes for the rabies vaccine to be performed yearly and then every 3 
years. The distemper and parvovirus vaccines are prescribed to be given yearly. The licensee states she was not aware 
the rabies vaccine was required.  
 
The following 30 dogs have no history of receiving a rabies vaccine:

The following 1 dog has no history of vaccinations for distemper, parvovirus, or rabies:

Distemper, parvovirus, and rabies are life-threatening diseases, and, if contracted, may cause pain, distress, and 
suffering. Correct by vaccinating for distemper, parvovirus, and rabies in accordance with a schedule approved by the 
Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations. Correct by May 12, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
